title: Israel bombs more Gaza City high-rises after forced evacuation orders

title: Cancelled concert shows political, social rifts in Iran amid war tensions

title: Tunisia flotilla eager to join Global Sumud mission to break Gaza siege

title: Medicine is being invented in Gaza
summary: As medical students in Gaza, we are taught how to save lives with nothing and how to make impossible decisions.

title: What scientists have learned from the biggest ever collision of black holes
summary: Massive black holes may not always be formed the way we thought.

title: After Trump jab, India’s Modi says ties with US still ‘very positive’
summary: Modi's remarks follow Trump reaffirming personal friendship, downplaying earlier remarks about 'losing India' to China.

title: Australian neo-Nazi attack on sacred Indigenous site a worrying trend
summary: Attack on site sacred to Aboriginal community followed an anti-immigration rally in Melbourne city.

title: Israel acts with “absolute impunity” in Gaza occupation plan
summary: Analyst Tahani Mustafa says Israel acts with no red lines as its allies offer little pushback on Gaza occupation plan.

title: Gaza-ville : Israël rase un nouvel immeuble après avoir ordonné son évacuation
summary: L'armée israélienne a annoncé, samedi après-midi, avoir ciblé une tour d'immeuble à Gaza-ville, qu'elle accuse d'être utilisée par le Hamas. Quelques heures plus tôt, Israël avait déclaré la mise en place d'une zone dite "humanitaire" à Al-Mawasi, dans le sud de l'enclave palestinienne, sommant les habitants de Gaza-ville de s'y rendre

title: À Gaza, l’armée israélienne dirige les déplacés vers des zones dangereuses ou déjà occupées
summary: L’armée israélienne incite les habitants de la ville de Gaza à évacuer vers de prétendues "vastes zones vides" du sud de l’enclave. Nombre de ces zones – où de nouvelles tentes sont apparues ces derniers jours – sont pourtant déjà largement occupées ou se situent dans un périmètre jugé dangereux par l’armée. Sur place, nos Observateurs racontent la difficulté à trouver un endroit où s'installer.

title: À Gaza-ville, la peur des habitants après l'annonce de nouvelles frappes
summary: L'armée israélienne a frappé vendredi 6 septembre une tour d'immeuble dans la ville de Gaza, qu'Israël menace d'une offensive militaire majeure. Selon Rami Abou Jammous, journaliste indépendant à Gaza-ville, la peur grandit chez les habitants. "J'habite à 500-600 mètres de la tour touchée et on sait que ça va bientôt être notre tour. On prépare nos valises, mais on ne sait pas où aller. Tous nos souvenirs peuvent disparaître en trois secondes", témoigne-t-il sur notre antenne.

title: De l’aide humanitaire non livrée à Gaza ? Les ONG contestent
summary: Des influenceurs pro-israéliens affirment que l’aide humanitaire s’entasse et pourri au point de passage de Kerem Shalom parce que les ONG et l’ONU ne la livre pas. Une version contestée par les organisations internationales.

title: Gaza : jusqu’où ira Benjamin Netanyahou ?
summary: Jusqu’où ira la guerre à Gaza ? Alors que les trois-quarts du territoire palestinien sont aujourd’hui contrôlés par Israël, Benjamin Netanyahou se dit déterminé à aller "jusqu'au bout". La libération des otages, elle, semble encore plus complexe à imaginer. Alors que les États-Unis n’ont pas renoncé à leur plan de faire de Gaza la "Riviera du Proche-Orient", quel sort sera réservé aux plus de deux millions de Gazaouis aujourd’hui menacés par la famine ?

title: Gaza : l'armée israélienne détruit une tour d'immeuble, le Hamas publie une vidéo de deux otages
summary: L'armée israélienne a frappé, vendredi dans la ville de Gaza, une tour d'immeuble, qui s'est écroulée comme un château de cartes. De son côté, le Hamas a diffusé une vidéo montrant deux otages israéliens enlevés le 7 octobre 2023.

title: Liban : l'armée va commencer à désarmer le Hezbollah, annonce le gouvernement
summary: À l'issue d'une réunion du gouvernement, le ministre libanais de l'Information a indiqué vendredi que l'armée libanaise allait commencer à mettre en œuvre le plan de désarmement du Hezbollah. Les détails de ce plan resteront "secrets".

title: L'armée israélienne affirme avoir pris le contrôle de 40 % de la ville de Gaza
summary: Les troupes israéliennes contrôlent désormais 40 % de la ville de Gaza, a indiqué jeudi soir le porte-parole de l'armée israélienne, Effie Defrin, et ce alors que l'État hébreu n'a jamais annoncé publiquement le début de l'offensive pour s'emparer de cette ville

title: De l'aide non distribuée à Gaza ? Les ONG contestent les récits d’influenceurs pro-Israël
summary: De la nourriture non livrée en plein Gaza ? Depuis fin juillet, des influenceurs invités par l'armée israélienne filment le checkpoint de Kerem Shalom dans Gaza qu'ils montrent rempli d'aide humanitaire non livrée, pour soutenir qu'Israël n'est pas responsable de la famine. Des affirmations rejetées par toutes les ONGs interrogées, qui décrivent la difficulté et la dangerosité à livrer de l'aide actuellement, par ailleurs toujours insuffisante.

title: Gaza : une rentrée des classes sous les bombes israéliennes
summary: Au moins 21.000 enfants vivent avec un handicap causé par la guerre à Gaza entre Israël et le Hamas depuis le 7 octobre 2023, soit plus de la moitié de l'ensemble des enfants blessés, a indiqué le Comité des droits des personnes handicapées (CDPH), organe des Nations unies. Au total, quelque 40.500 enfants ont souffert de "blessures provoquées par la guerre" en près de deux ans, a précisé ce comité composé d'experts qui se réunit deux fois par an à Genève.

title: Egypte : un garçon à tout prix ! Le business de la sélection du genre
summary: Partout en Egypte, des cliniques proposant aux couples de choisir le sexe de leur futur enfant ont pignon sur rue. Avoir au moins un garçon est considéré comme indispensable pour de nombreux Égyptiens, dans les villages en particulier. Si cette pratique est strictement interdite partout en Europe, en Egypte un flou juridique subsiste qui permet sa pratique. Les cliniques de FIV profitent de ce vide législatif pour faire leur publicité à destination des Égyptiens. Reportage de Mathilde Delvigne.

title: Israël s'attend à la fuite d'un million d'habitants de Gaza-ville, menacée d'une opération militaire
summary: Alors que la Défense civile de Gaza a fait état mercredi de 62 morts, Israël a affirmé s'attendre à ce qu'un million de Palestiniens fuient Gaza-ville en raison de l'opération militaire prévue par son armée. Dans la soirée à Jérusalem, des manifestants sont redescendus dans la rue à l'appel des familles d'otages.

title: Gaza : l'armée israélienne réintègre ses réservistes en vue d'une offensive sur la ville de Gaza
summary: Israël intensifie mardi 2 septembre ses préparatifs militaires en réintégrant dans ses rangs des milliers de réservistes en vue d'une offensive annoncée sur la ville de Gaza, après près de deux années de guerre contre le Hamas.

title: L'armée israélienne réintègre ses réservistes en vue d'une offensive sur la ville de Gaza
summary: Alors qu'Israël accélère ses préparatifs en vue d'"opérations de combat étendues" pour prendre la ville de Gaza, le président français Emmanuel Macron a mis en garde mardi l'État hébreu contre toute "offensive" ou "tentative d’annexion" de territoires, affirmant que cela n’arrêterait pas le mouvement de reconnaissance de l’État palestinien.

title: L'actu en dessin : une campagne internationale pour le droit d'informer à Gaza
summary: Une mobilisation internationale suivie par de très nombreux médias a eu lieu lundi à l’initiative des ONG Reporters sans frontières (RSF) et Avaaz. L'objectif était à la fois de dénoncer les attaques israéliennes contre les journalistes à Gaza mais aussi de réclamer l'ouverture de l'enclave palestinienne à la presse internationale.

title: Le journaliste Rami Abou Jamous raconte l’offensive israélienne dans la ville de Gaza : « La première tour visée, c’est juste à côté de chez moi »
summary: Vendredi 5 septembre, une première tour d’immeuble a été bombardée dans la ville de Gaza, sous les yeux de Rami Abou Jamous et de son fils.

title: Les messages envoyés par la Chine lors de son défilé militaire : « Vous avez le choix entre la paix et la guerre »
summary: Missile nucléaire, drones… Pékin a présenté beaucoup de nouveautés dans son armement. Joseph Henrotin, spécialiste des stratégies militaires, nous explique les messages qu’a voulu faire passer la Chine au reste du monde lors de ce défilé XXL.

title: L’équipe Israel-Premier Tech efface la mention « Israel » de ses maillots sur le Tour d’Espagne
summary: Dirigée par Sylvan Adams, soutien du premier ministre Benyamin Netanyahou et dont la carte de visite stipulait « ambassadeur autoproclamé d’Israël » au lancement de l’équipe, la formation cristallise l’attention.

title: En direct, guerre en Ukraine : le premier ministre canadien, Mark Carney, appelle à maintenir une pression maximale sur la Russie
summary: « M. Poutine est la cause de cette guerre, il est la raison des morts. Il ne dictera pas les conditions de la paix », a-t-il affirmé alors que Volodymyr Zelensky a déclaré, samedi, qu’il refusait de rencontrer le président russe à Moscou.

title: En direct, Gaza : Israël a détruit une deuxième tour de la ville de Gaza ; des manifestations propalestiniennes à Paris, Londres et Madrid
summary: L’armée israélienne a appelé, samedi matin, les habitants de la ville de Gaza à partir vers une « zone humanitaire » à Khan Younès, dans le sud de l’enclave.

title: « Le sommet de Tianjin constitue l’acte de naissance du Sud global »
summary: L’événement, organisé par Xi Jinping, auquel ont participé une vingtaine de dirigeants, dont Narendra Modi et Vladimir Poutine, a donné à voir un nouvel ordre international, marqué par l’ascension de la puissance chinoise et l’essoufflement de l’hégémonie américaine, analysent, dans une tribune au « Monde », les chercheurs Stéphanie Balme et Christophe Jaffrelot.

title: Un message d’adieu généré par IA pour 15 euros : l’essor des « résurrections » numériques chez les proches des soldats russes morts en Ukraine
summary: Pour une somme modique, il est possible de mettre en scène le défunt s’élevant dans les airs, se transformant en oiseau ou étreignant ses enfants.

title: Au Liban, la mission de la Finul devrait s’achever à la fin de 2026
summary: Sous la pression des Etats-Unis et d’Israël, la Force intérimaire des Nations unies au Liban, constituée de 10 800 casques bleus, mettra fin à son mandat le 31 décembre 2026. Après quoi, l’armée libanaise sera la seule à assurer la sécurité dans le sud du pays.

title: Royaume-Uni : Keir Starmer remanie un gouvernement Labour dans la tourmente
summary: En pleine crise un an à peine après l’arrivée au pouvoir du Labour, la populaire vice-première ministre, Angela Rayner, s’est vue contrainte de démissionner. Elle est remplacée par David Lammy, le ministre des affaires étrangères, lui-même remplacé par Yvette Cooper.

title: Washington cible des ONG palestiniennes de défense des droits humains coopérant avec la CPI
summary: Les Etats-Unis poursuivent leur campagne contre la Cour pénale internationale. Après avoir sanctionné ses juges et ses procureurs, Washington vise cette fois les ONG qui enquêtent à Gaza et en Cisjordanie sur les crimes du pouvoir israélien.

title: La Silicon Valley prend un virage militaire inédit, de Google à Palantir
summary: Reflet d’un bouleversement culturel majeur, des entreprises de tech américaines telles Meta, OpenAI ou Google s’autorisent désormais à être actives dans les secteurs militaire et de la sécurité nationale, rejoignant les pionniers Palantir ou Anduril.

title: L’Autriche empêtrée dans la stagflation
summary: Le pays d’Europe centrale souffre d’une inflation soutenue et d’une croissance au point mort. Pour réduire le déficit public, attendu à 4,4 % du produit intérieur brut en 2025, le gouvernement de coalition envisage de sous-indexer les pensions de retraite et les salaires des fonctionnaires en 2026.

title: Le Japon célèbre la majorité du prince Hisahito, seul jeune héritier masculin au trône
summary: La princesse Aiko, 23 ans, enfant unique de l’empereur Naruhito, ne peut pas succéder à son père, selon une règle en vigueur depuis 1947, car c’est une femme.

title: Au Liban, le plan de désarmement du Hezbollah pourrait rapidement se retrouver dans une impasse
summary: Si le gouvernement a bien endossé le plan de désarmement de la formation chiite, Beyrouth, comme le Parti de Dieu, en conditionnent le succès à l’arrêt des violations israéliennes. Or l’Etat hébreu exige sa mise en œuvre avant toute mesure de réciprocité.

title: En Norvège, les ONG alertent sur la pauvreté
summary: L’économie et les inégalités sociales sont en tête des préoccupations des électeurs avant les élections législatives du 8 septembre. Ces trois dernières années, le coût de la vie a augmenté dans le pays, affectant particulièrement les plus vulnérables.

title: Arrests made at demonstration against Palestine Action proscription in London
summary:
Arrests made at demonstration against Palestine Action proscription in London

Submitted by MEE staff on Sat, 09/06/2025 - 16:59
Protesters were told to withhold details from police to force mass processing at stations
An elderly protester is taken away by police officers at a "Lift The Ban" demonstration in support of the proscribed group Palestine Action, calling for the recently imposed ban to be lifted, in Parliament Square, central London, on September 6, 2025.
Off

Police in London have arrested protesters calling for Palestine Action to have its proscription as a terrorist group repealed.

Hundreds had gathered in Westminster's Parliament Square holding placards reading "I support Palestine Action" and opposing Israel's ongoing genocide in Gaza.

“Officers have begun making arrests for expressing support for proscribed terror organisation Palestine Action at the protest organised by Defend Our Juries," the Metropolitan Police said in a statement.

Defend Our Juries (DOJ), which has staged regular protests since the government moved to proscribe Palestine Action in July, told protesters who signed up for Saturday’s demonstration to withhold their details from officers to force mass processing at police stations.

The group had scheduled a press conference on Tuesday to announce that an estimated 1,500 people were going to risk arrest under the Terrorism Act for holding signs reading, “I oppose genocide. I support Palestine Action.”

But the conference was postponed after seven of its key speakers, including former government lawyer Tim Crosland, were arrested under section 12 of the Terrorism Act 2000. DOJ said arrestees had been held over the custody time limit of 24 hours and had their homes raided.

Israel's genocide in Gaza

title: Six Palestinians die of starvation in Gaza in 24 hours
summary:
Six Palestinians die of starvation in Gaza in 24 hours

Six Palestinians, including a child, died in the past 24 hours from starvation and malnutrition in the Gaza Strip, Wafa news agency reported, citing medical sources.

The deaths bring the total number of starvation-related fatalities in the enclave to 382, including 135 children, the agency said.

title: Israeli forces open fire in West Bank town of Beit Fajjar
summary:
Israeli forces open fire in West Bank town of Beit Fajjar

Sources told Al Jazeera Arabic Israeli forces opened fire during a raid on the town of Beit Fajjar, south of Bethlehem in the occupied West Bank.

The escalation comes as the war on Gaza, ongoing since October 2023, has killed more than 64,000 Palestinians and injured over 161,000, most of them women and children.

title: One child killed every hour in Gaza war: Save the Children
summary:
One child killed every hour in Gaza war: Save the Children

Save the Children says that on average at least one Palestinian child has been killed every hour in Gaza during nearly 23 months of war.

Figures from Gaza authorities show more than 20,000 children – about two percent of the territory’s child population – have been killed since October 2023. Among them are at least 1,009 babies under the age of one, with nearly half born and killed during the war.

“This is a shameful statistic – a horrific new low in a war characterised by a constant stream of them,” said Ahmad Alhendawi, Save the Children’s regional director for the Middle East, North Africa and Eastern Europe.

“Worst of all, we saw this coming. Systematic attacks on children’s homes, playgrounds, schools and hospitals, starvation by design – the world is doing nothing to stop it.”

title: Turkey's CHP to hold extraordinary congress after court dismisses Istanbul leadership
summary:
Turkey's CHP to hold extraordinary congress after court dismisses Istanbul leadership

Submitted by Alex MacDonald on Sat, 09/06/2025 - 13:53
Istanbul leader Ozgur Celik and 195 other officials were removed from their positions over 'irregularities' earlier this week
Supporters of the Republican People’s Party rally in Istanbul for the city’s jailed mayor, Ekrem Imamoglu, on 3 September 2025 (Ozan Kose/AFP)
Off

Turkey's main opposition Republican People's Party (CHP) will hold an extraordinary congress on 21 September after a court dismissed its Istanbul leadership over charges the party says were politically motivated.

Earlier this week, a court annulled the results of the party's October 2023 Istanbul provincial congress, leading to the removal of provincial leader Ozgur Celik and 195 other officials.

The 45th Civil Court of First Instance said that allegations of irregularities in the congress had been "approximately proven".

The court appointed a five-member team to replace the leadership, including former MP Gursel Tekin, who resigned in February 2024 due to the change in national leadership. 

News of the ruling caused the Turkish stock market to plunge 5.5 percent.

A source told AFP that the CHP would convene its extraordinary congress amid fears the dismissal of its Istanbul chair could be a precursor to a similar ruling against the national leadership.

Leader Ozgur Ozel and his allies are currently embroiled in a nearly identical legal process that will resume in Ankara on 15 September.

The CHP, Turkey’s largest opposition party, has accused President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and the ruling Justice and Development Party (AK Party) of targeting them after its widespread success in the 2024 local elections.

Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu, a popular opposition leader and upcoming presidential candidate who could potentially challenge Erdogan, was arrested on 19 March.

A number of other CHP mayors, officials and politicians have also been swept up in arrests since then.

The arrests have sparked regular street protests and rallies by opposition leaders and activists, including those unaffiliated with the CHP. Authorities have responded by detaining nearly 2,000 people, most of whom were later released.

Imamoglu’s arrest has galvanised a wide cross-section of Turkish society, who see it as perhaps the final nail in the coffin of an already fragile democracy.

Turkey Politics
News

title: In the West, it is a crime to deny one Holocaust and dangerous to name another
summary:
In the West, it is a crime to deny one Holocaust and dangerous to name another

The difference between Holocaust denial and Gaza Genocide denial is that Holocaust denial is illegal or a criminal offence in many countries, and is, for the most part, the preserve of marginalised kooks and conspiracy theorists.

No self-respecting journalist considers Holocaust denial a legitimate point of view, and no serious media organisation argues that impartiality requires it to provide Holocaust denial with a platform in any serious discussion about Germany's extermination of Europe's Jews during World War Two - let alone equal time, or beginning and ending every such discussion with "Germany said".

Gaza Genocide denial, by contrast, is a well-organised and orchestrated global campaign sponsored, funded, and avidly promoted - without any hindrance whatsoever - by the regime perpetrating the genocide.

In many states, Gaza Genocide denial counts among its champions elected and other senior officials, influential lobbies and powerful organisations. Its messages are amplified by an international network of conspiracy theorists, fanatic ideologues and hired hands.

Serious media organisations not only consider it a journalistic requirement to give Gaza Genocide denial a platform and equal time, but they also routinely communicate Israel's talking points to their audiences. The BBC's compulsive resort to "Israel says" is a case in point.

Read more:  In the West, it is a crime to deny one Holocaust and dangerous to name another

title: Israeli strikes kill at least 41 in Gaza as starvation deaths climb to 376
summary:
Israeli strikes kill at least 41 in Gaza as starvation deaths climb to 376

Medical sources in Gaza told Al Jazeera Arabic at least 41 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli fire since dawn on Saturday.

According to the Health Ministry, Israel’s ongoing war has left more than 64,000 dead and 162,000 wounded.

The ministry also confirmed that 376 people, including 134 children, have died from starvation since the start of the assault.

title: London protesters demand end to ban on Palestine Action group
summary:
London protesters demand end to ban on Palestine Action group

Protesters gathered in London demanding the government lift its ban on Palestine Action, a group outlawed days after it admitted breaking into an air force base in southern England. Authorities said the raid caused around £7m ($9.3m) in damage to two aircraft.

In Parliament Square, demonstrators surrounded a small group of officers as police made several arrests. Authorities warned that anyone attending the rally would be acting unlawfully and could face detention.

Elsewhere in the capital, hundreds more joined marches in solidarity with Palestinians in Gaza, urging the UK government to halt arms sales to Israel and take meaningful action.

title: Elbit Systems factory apparently shuttered following Palestine Action campaign
summary:
Elbit Systems factory apparently shuttered following Palestine Action campaign

One of defence company Elbit Systems' plants in the UK city of Bristol has reportedly been closed in the wake of a Palestine Action campaign, according to The Guardian.

The Elbit Systems UK site in Aztec West business park was repeatedly targeted by activists, including the day before the group was proscribed as a terrorist organisation by then Home Secretary Yvette Cooper. Actions included lock-ons, rooftop occupations, smashing windows and covering the building in red paint.

The Guardian visited the site earlier this week and said the property was deserted, with "no staff present aside from a security guard stationed in a vehicle parked outside the premises".

The Israeli company, which has drawn criticism for producing weaponry used in the ongoing genocide in Gaza, had held the lease since 2019, with a contract due to run until 2029.

Read more: Elbit Systems factory apparently shuttered following Palestine Action campaign

title: Israeli strikes kill 35 in Gaza, including six seeking aid
summary:
Israeli strikes kill 35 in Gaza, including six seeking aid

At least 35 people have been killed in Gaza since dawn, including six civilians seeking aid, medical sources told Al Jazeera Arabic.

Twenty-five of the deaths occurred in Gaza City, as Israeli forces continued their assault on the territory’s largest urban centre.

title: Israeli strike destroys Gaza City residential tower
summary:
Israeli strike destroys Gaza City residential tower

Israeli air strikes demolished the Al-Sousi residential tower in Tal al-Hawa, southwest of Gaza City, less than an hour after Israeli forces ordered residents to evacuate.

The attack occurred opposite the Unrwa headquarters.

The Israeli army said it targeted the tower because it allegedly contained intelligence equipment and observation points used to monitor troop movements. Israel has regularly claimed that it targets military objectives within civilian infrastructure, but it rarely provides evidence, and its claims are often disproven.

Gaza’s Government Information Office dismissed the Israeli claims, saying the towers are under surveillance and only civilians are permitted inside. The office said allegations of militant activity are part of a “deception policy” aimed at forcibly displacing residents.

— القسطل الإخباري (@AlQastalps) September 6, 2025

title: US sanctions Palestinian rights groups over ICC cases against Israel
summary:
US sanctions Palestinian rights groups over ICC cases against Israel

The United States has placed three leading Palestinian rights organisations – Al-Haq, the Palestinian Centre for Human Rights (PCHR), and Al Mezan – on its sanctions list. The Department of the Treasury confirmed the groups were added on Thursday to its “Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List.”

US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said the organisations were targeted because they had “directly engaged in efforts by the International Criminal Court (ICC) to investigate, arrest, detain, or prosecute Israeli nationals, without Israel’s consent.”

The Trump administration had earlier imposed sanctions on the ICC after it launched investigations and issued arrest warrants for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former Defence Minister Yoav Gallant over alleged war crimes in Gaza.

title: Israeli attacks kill 84 in Gaza in 24 hours as toll climbs past 64,000
summary:
Israeli attacks kill 84 in Gaza in 24 hours as toll climbs past 64,000

Gaza’s Health Ministry says at least 84 Palestinians were killed and 338 wounded in the past 24 hours as Israel’s bombardment continues to devastate the besieged territory.

The ministry reported that many victims remain trapped under rubble or in the streets, with ambulance and civil defence crews unable to reach them.

Among the dead were 17 people shot while trying to collect desperately needed aid, with another 174 wounded. This brings the total number of Palestinians killed while seeking aid to 2,356, and more than 17,244 injured.

Officials also added 401 previously unregistered deaths after verifying the victims’ identities. According to the ministry, Israel’s assault has now killed at least 64,231 Palestinians and wounded 161,583 since 7 October 2023.

title: Six, including child, die of hunger in Gaza as toll reaches 382
summary:
Six, including child, die of hunger in Gaza as toll reaches 382

Gaza’s Health Ministry said six people, including a child, died of hunger in the past 24 hours as starvation deepens under the continuing Israeli blockade.

The ministry reported that the death toll from malnutrition has now reached 382, with 135 of the victims children.

title: Elbit Systems factory apparently shuttered following Palestine Action campaign
summary:
Elbit Systems factory apparently shuttered following Palestine Action campaign

Submitted by MEE staff on Sat, 09/06/2025 - 10:29
The defence company's plant in Bristol is reportedly empty in the wake of a direct action campaign by the now-proscribed group
Protesters hold placards during a 'Lift the Ban' demonstration in support of the proscribed group Palestine Action, calling for the ban to be lifted, in Parliament Square, central London, on 9 August 2025 (Henry Nicholls/AFP)
Off

One of defence company Elbit Systems' plants in the UK city of Bristol has reportedly been closed in the wake of a Palestine Action campaign, according to The Guardian.

The Elbit Systems UK site in Aztec West business park was repeatedly targeted by activists, including the day before the group was proscribed as a terrorist organisation by then Home Secretary Yvette Cooper. Actions included lock-ons, rooftop occupations, smashing windows and covering the building in red paint.

The Guardian visited the site earlier this week and said the property was deserted, with "no staff present aside from a security guard stationed in a vehicle parked outside the premises".

The Israeli company, which has drawn criticism for producing weaponry used in the ongoing genocide in Gaza, had held the lease since 2019, with a contract due to run until 2029.

Elbit Systems provides around 85 percent of Israel’s drones and land-based military equipment and has played a major role in supplying Israel with weaponry for its genocide in Gaza.

Private Eye reported last month that the company's British arm, Elbit Systems UK Limited, was close to winning a major contract that would make it a "strategic partner" of Britain's Ministry of Defence (MoD).

The Guardian's report comes as the UK has continued to crack down on supporters of Palestine Action, with police rounding up activists in dawn raids.

Earlier this week, six campaigners seeking to lift the UK government's ban on Palestine Action were charged with terrorism offences for allegedly expressing support for the group.

Defend Our Juries (DOJ) said on Tuesday that six of its key spokespeople had been rounded up in dawn raids, hours before a scheduled news conference announcing that a mass action to challenge the ban would be going ahead this Saturday.

Police said the charges were part of an investigation led by the Counter Terrorism Command, related to the alleged organisation of protests and 13 Zoom calls in support of Palestine Action.

The spokespeople, including former government lawyer Tim Crosland, were held over the custody time limit of 24 hours and had their homes raided, according to DOJ.

DOJ said that during a hearing at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Thursday, the judge granted the defendants bail, rejecting a request by the Crown Prosecution Service to hold them on remand.

The UK government proscribed Palestine Action under anti-terror laws on 4 July, following an incident in which members broke into RAF Brize Norton and attacked with paint and crowbars two planes they said were “used for military operations in Gaza and across the Middle East". 

The designation puts Palestine Action on a par with al-Qaeda and the Islamic State group, making it a criminal offence under British law to show support for or invite support for the group - punishable by up to 14 years in prison under the Terrorism Act 2000.

Israel's genocide in Gaza
